questions.text: An individual experiences sudden death, and their ECG reveals ST segment elevation in leads V1-V3 along with right bundle branch block. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Brugada syndrome is characterized by a distinctive ECG pattern showing ST segment elevation in right precordial leads (V1-V3) with a right bundle branch block (RBBB) appearance. This genetic disorder affects cardiac sodium channels and predisposes patients to ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, especially during sleep or rest. The ECG abnormalities can wax and wane over time and may become more pronounced during acute illness and fever. The pattern includes a coved ST elevation followed by a negative T wave in the right precordial leads.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Though HOCM is a cause of sudden cardiac death, its ECG findings typically include left ventricular hypertrophy, deep Q waves in lateral and inferior leads, and ST-T wave abnormalities. It does not produce the characteristic ST elevation in V1-V3 with RBBB pattern seen in Brugada syndrome.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM):
  • • Option B. Aortic valve stenosis: While aortic stenosis can cause sudden death, its ECG findings typically include left ventricular hypertrophy and ST-T wave abnormalities in lateral leads. It doesn't cause the specific pattern of ST elevation in V1-V3 with RBBB seen in this case.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Aortic valve stenosis:
  • • Option D. Ashman phenomenon: This is a conduction abnormality characterized by aberrant ventricular conduction (typically RBBB morphology) following a short-long R-R interval sequence. It is not associated with ST elevation in V1-V3 and is not a cause of sudden cardiac death.
  • • Option
  • • D. Ashman phenomenon:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brugada syndrome presents with a distinctive ECG pattern of ST elevation in right precordial leads (V1-V3) with RBBB appearance and is an important cause of sudden cardiac death in structurally normal hearts, especially in young adults.

questions.text: Which enzyme catalyzes the conversion of a compound into IP3 and DAG? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Phospholipase C (PLC) is the enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) in the cell membrane to generate two important second messengers: inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). This reaction occurs when a ligand binds to a receptor (either G-protein coupled or tyrosine kinase receptor) that activates PLC. Subsequently, IP3 diffuses to the endoplasmic reticulum where it triggers calcium release, while DAG remains in the membrane to activate protein kinase C.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option a. Adenylyl cyclase : This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP), not IP3 and DAG. It's activated by stimulatory G-proteins (Gs) after receptor binding and generates cAMP as a second messenger. Option b. Guanylyl cyclase : This enzyme catalyzes the formation of cyclic GMP (cGMP) from GTP. It exists in both membrane-bound and soluble forms, with the latter activated by nitric oxide. It does not produce IP3 or DAG. Option d. Phospholipase A : This enzyme cleaves fatty acids from the sn-2 position of membrane phospholipids, generating arachidonic acid and lysophospholipids. It's involved in the production of eicosanoids but not IP3 or DAG.
  • • Option a. Adenylyl cyclase : This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP), not IP3 and DAG. It's activated by stimulatory G-proteins (Gs) after receptor binding and generates cAMP as a second messenger.
  • • Option a. Adenylyl cyclase
  • • Option b. Guanylyl cyclase : This enzyme catalyzes the formation of cyclic GMP (cGMP) from GTP. It exists in both membrane-bound and soluble forms, with the latter activated by nitric oxide. It does not produce IP3 or DAG.
  • • Option b. Guanylyl cyclase
  • • Option d. Phospholipase A : This enzyme cleaves fatty acids from the sn-2 position of membrane phospholipids, generating arachidonic acid and lysophospholipids. It's involved in the production of eicosanoids but not IP3 or DAG.
  • • Option d. Phospholipase A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The phosphoinositide signaling pathway involves phospholipase C-mediated hydrolysis of PIP2 to generate two distinct second messengers (IP3 and DAG) that work in tandem to increase intracellular calcium and activate protein kinase C, coordinating comprehensive cellular responses.

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients is ( INICET Nov 2023
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In hospitalized patients, the most common cause of hypercalcemia is malignancy. Malignancy-associated hypercalcemia often results from the secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by cancer cells, which mimics the effects of parathyroid hormone, leading to increased calcium levels. This is frequently seen in cancers such as breast cancer, lung cancer, and multiple myeloma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Primary hyperparathyroidism: This is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in outpatients but not in hospitalized patients. It is characterized by elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to parathyroid gland hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma.
  • • Option B. Primary hyperparathyroidism:
  • • Option C. Vitamin D toxicity: Hypercalcemia can occur due to excessive intake of vitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium. However, it is not the most common cause in hospitalized patients.
  • • Option C. Vitamin D toxicity:
  • • Option D. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia: This is a rare genetic condition characterized by benign hypercalcemia with low urinary calcium excretion. It mimics primary hyperparathyroidism but is less common and typically not seen as the most frequent cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients.
  • • Option D. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignancy is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients, often due to the secretion of PTHrP by cancer cells.

questions.text: A positive direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test indicates:
questions.correct_answer: C. Hemolytic disease of the newborn
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hemolytic disease of the newborn

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT), also known as the direct Coombs test, indicates that antibodies or complement proteins are bound to the surface of red blood cells. This test is commonly used to diagnose hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN). HDN occurs when maternal antibodies cross the placenta and target fetal red blood cells, leading to their destruction. This immune-mediated hemolysis results in neonatal anemia and hyperbilirubinemia. The positive DAT confirms the presence of these antibodies on the fetal red blood cells, supporting the diagnosis of HDN.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Congenital red cell aplasia: This is a non-immune condition where there is a failure in red blood cell production, not related to antibody-mediated hemolysis.
  • • Option A. Congenital red cell aplasia:
  • • Option B. Hereditary spherocytosis: This is a non-immune hemolytic anemia caused by a defect in the red cell membrane, leading to spherical-shaped red cells that are prone to hemolysis.
  • • Option B. Hereditary spherocytosis:
  • • Option D. G6PD deficiency: This is a non-immune hemolytic anemia caused by an enzyme deficiency that makes red blood cells more susceptible to oxidative stress.
  • • Option D. G6PD deficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A positive direct anti-globulin (Coombs) test is indicative of hemolytic disease of the newborn, an immune-mediated condition.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows: pH = 7.30, HCO3 = 10 mEq/L, PaCO2 = 20 mmHg, which is suggestive of partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.correct_answer: B. Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The ABG values indicate metabolic acidosis (low HCO3 with a low pH). The PaCO2 is 20 mmHg, which is lower than the expected value calculated using Winter's formula:
  • • Expected PaCO2 = (1.5 × HCO3) + 8 ± 2 = (1.5 × 10) + 8 ± 2 = 23 ± 2 mmHg.
  • • The observed PaCO2 (20 mmHg) is lower than the expected value, indicating excessive respiratory compensation through hyperventilation, leading to increased CO2 washout.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout : This would result in a higher-than-expected PaCO2, worsening acidosis, and does not explain the observed findings.
  • • Option A. Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout
  • • Option C. Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO3 -: This mechanism compensates for metabolic acidosis but does not explain the respiratory findings here.
  • • Option C. Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO3
  • • Option D. Decreased excretion of H+ : This would exacerbate metabolic acidosis rather than represent a compensatory response.
  • • Option D. Decreased excretion of H+

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In metabolic acidosis, respiratory compensation via hyperventilation aims to reduce PaCO2, mitigating the acidosis. Comparing measured PaCO2 with the expected value helps identify appropriate or excessive respiratory compensation. Hyperventilation leading to increased CO2 washout is a common compensatory mechanism in metabolic acidosis.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harrison/Acid-Base Disorders/Chapter 318

It is a medical emergency, and the sudden-onset severe headache is a hallmark early symptom, often described as "thunderclap" in nature. Additional features may include:
  • • Pituitary apoplexy

  • • Visual disturbances: Due to compression of the optic chiasm. Nausea and vomiting: Resulting from increased intracranial pressure. Shock: Secondary to acute adrenal insufficiency caused by pituitary hormonal dysfunction. Altered mental status or unconsciousness: Seen in severe cases with significant intracranial pressure or hemorrhage.

  • • Nausea and vomiting: Resulting from increased intracranial pressure.
  • • Nausea and vomiting:
  • • Shock: Secondary to acute adrenal insufficiency caused by pituitary hormonal dysfunction.

  • • Altered mental status or unconsciousness: Seen in severe cases with significant intracranial pressure or hemorrhage.

  • • MRI is the diagnostic modality of choice, and management involves urgent IV glucocorticoids and, if necessary, surgical decompression.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism of hemolysis in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Intravascular hemolysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), intravascular hemolysis occurs due to the destruction of red blood cells within the circulation. This is caused by:
  • • paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH),
  • • Deficiency of CD55 and CD59: These proteins protect red blood cells from complement-mediated destruction. In PNH, a mutation in the PIG-A gene results in the absence of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins, including CD55 and CD59. Complement activation: Leads to uncontrolled lysis of red blood cells directly within blood vessels, resulting in hemoglobinuria, anemia, and other complications like thrombosis.
  • • Deficiency of CD55 and CD59: These proteins protect red blood cells from complement-mediated destruction. In PNH, a mutation in the PIG-A gene results in the absence of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins, including CD55 and CD59.
  • • Deficiency of CD55 and CD59:
  • • PIG-A gene
  • • Complement activation: Leads to uncontrolled lysis of red blood cells directly within blood vessels, resulting in hemoglobinuria, anemia, and other complications like thrombosis.
  • • Complement activation:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Extravascular hemolysis: Incorrect because PNH primarily involves intravascular hemolysis due to complement activation. Extravascular hemolysis occurs in conditions like hereditary spherocytosis, where red blood cells are destroyed in the spleen.
  • • Option A. Extravascular hemolysis:
  • • Option C. Autoimmune-mediated hemolysis: Incorrect because PNH is not autoimmune in nature. It is caused by an acquired somatic mutation in hematopoietic stem cells, not an immune system attack involving autoantibodies.
  • • Option C. Autoimmune-mediated hemolysis:
  • • Option D. Enzyme deficiency-mediated hemolysis: Incorrect because PNH is not due to an enzymatic defect like glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, which causes hemolysis after oxidative stress.
  • • Option D. Enzyme deficiency-mediated hemolysis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is characterized by intravascular hemolysis due to complement-mediated destruction of red blood cells lacking CD55 and CD59. The hallmark feature of PNH is hemoglobinuria, often leading to anemia and thrombotic complications. Prompt recognition and treatment with complement inhibitors like eculizumab are critical for improving outcomes.

These features are characteristic of CML, a type of leukemia where the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells. The presence of immature WBCs (a left shift) and massive splenomegaly are classic signs of CML.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. Despite this, the disease is progressing with worsening symptoms and joint damage evident on imaging. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: B
options.text: Add an anti-TNF alpha agent to the current regimen

options.label: C
options.text: Start parenteral corticosteroids and continue methotrexate

options.label: D
options.text: Increase methotrexate dose and monitor for response

questions.correct_answer: B. Add an anti-TNF alpha agent to the current regimen
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Add an anti-TNF alpha agent to the current regimen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • For patients with rheumatoid arthritis who show inadequate response to methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids after an adequate trial period, escalation of therapy is necessary. Anti-TNF alpha agents, such as infliximab, adalimumab, or etanercept, are potent biologic DMARDs that target key inflammatory pathways in rheumatoid arthritis. Adding an anti-TNF agent to methotrexate improves efficacy, reduces joint damage, and enhances overall disease control.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Stop methotrexate and initiate leflunomide : Switching from methotrexate to leflunomide may be an option in cases of methotrexate intolerance or contraindication, but it is not the preferred step in patients tolerating methotrexate who need better disease control.
  • • Option A. Stop methotrexate and initiate leflunomide
  • • Option C. Start parenteral corticosteroids and continue methotrexate : Parenteral corticosteroids may offer temporary relief but do not address long-term disease progression or modify disease activity.
  • • Option C. Start parenteral corticosteroids and continue methotrexate
  • • Option D. Increase methotrexate dose and monitor for response : Methotrexate dosing is typically maximized before considering additional therapies. If the patient is already on an optimal dose, adding another agent is warranted.
  • • Option D. Increase methotrexate dose and monitor for response

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of inadequate response to methotrexate and corticosteroids in rheumatoid arthritis, biologic agents like anti-TNF alpha inhibitors are effective and commonly used next steps. These agents can significantly improve disease outcomes by targeting specific cytokines involved in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis. Early intervention with biologics can prevent irreversible joint damage and disability.

questions.text: Arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows the following findings: (NEET PG 2021) pH: 7.52 HCO3: 30 mEq/L PaCO2: 45 mmHg Na: 123 mEq/L K: 3.2 mEq/L Cl: 67 mEq/L What is the cause of her ABG findings?
